recordings.loc: Wild River State Park, Chisago County, Minnesota
recordings.rmk:
Calling from on or near nest (we didn't discover the existence of the nest until the next day, but the call was coming from the general vicinity of the nest). 

Recorded with homemade parabolic reflector and Olympus LS-10S. Minor filtering of low frequencies, and one short segment of talking deleted. Some human background noise remains.
Four recordings of one bird pasted together. It was given in flight as well as from a dead snag. I only saw the one bird while I was recording this.

recordings.loc: Brule River State Forest, Douglas County, Wisconsin
recordings.rmk: The hawk in this recording is being scolded by a pair of Hermit Thrushes. link:http://www.wisconsinbirdsounds.com/broad-winged_hawk.php
Cries from an imm. following along behind a second, silent bird.

recordings.loc: Caroline (near  Brooktondale), Tompkins County, New York

recordings.rmk: Bird was circling directly overhead. Captured a few calls as it slowly drifted further away. Predominantly aspen forest. https://ebird.org/canada/view/checklist/S46360002

This bird was presumably on territory, due to the time of year. A fairly large nest was seen, but the bird itself was not. The vegetation was thick, as it was mid-summer, so it was difficult to get a look above, which is presumably where the bird was calling from. The calls were most likely as the result of entering the bird's territory. The habitat is a mixed woods consisting of hemlocks and other conifers in with various hardwoods. Adjacent to the woods is a bog/marsh area. The recording was not modified except to clip the beginning.
Calling repeatedly from unseen location.

recordings.loc: Schoolhouse Gap Trail, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Tennessee
recordings.rmk: Two birds on a dead snag, one flew off and came back at second 42 at which time they jumped at each other and the perched one flew off
There were 2 adult hawks and at least one immature. The adults were circling overhead and warning me.
Bird in coastal Cecropia. Human voices in background.
